isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - ELECTRONIC ENGINES, CATERPILLAR C-10 AND C-12 ENGINES - OPERATION - Engine Brake

svcproc.title: Engine Brake
svcproc.para: These Caterpillar engines come with an engine brake. This manual discusses only engine brake control circuits and components installed by International: the engine brake on/off switch (170), the engine brake selector switch (171) and the connecting circuits. The International installed clutch switch (376) and service brake switch (69) also provide inputs to the engine brake control system.
For a complete description of engine brake operation, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.
There are two owner selected engine brake operation modes, which are COAST and LATCH.
If the COAST mode (standard mode) is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is off the throttle pedal (throttle position less than 7%).
The service brake pedal is depressed (engine brake only operates while service brake is applied).
The cruise control switch can be in the on position, although it will be disabled by applying the service brake.

svcproc.para: If the LATCH mode is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is off the throttle pedal (throttle position less than 7%).
The cruise control switch must be off.

The engine brake operates when the driver applies the service brake, but the engine brake continues to operate (latches on, so to speak) after the driver takes his foot off the brake. The engine brake stays engaged (latched on) until one of the other ECM inputs changes: clutch pedal depressed, throttle pedal depressed, engine speed drops below 800 rpm or the brake pedal is depressed a second time.

svcproc.para: Control of the engine brake is shared by the driver and the ECM. The driver turns the engine brake on or off and selects how much engine brake is desired (number of cylinders). The ECM monitors certain engine parameters, then enables the engine brake system when all conditions are acceptable.

An on/off switch (170) is used to enable (turn on) the engine brake control system. With the on/off switch closed, the circuit between ECM connector (1014) terminal 5 and the engine brake selector switch terminal 2 is complete.
The engine brake selector switch (171) has three circuits: Low, Medium and a common or ground circuit connected to the engine brake on/off switch.

Selector switch terminal 1 is connected by circuit 24A to the engine brake on/off switch (170) at terminal 5. When the on/off switch is on, the circuit between the engine brake selector switch (171) terminal 5 and ECM connector (1014) terminal 5 is complete.
With the selector switch (171) in the Low position, the ECM sees a 0-volt signal at connector (1014) terminal 23 and a 5-volt signal at terminal 40.
With the selector switch (171) in the Medium position, the ECM sees a 0-volt signal at connector (1014) terminal 40 and a 5-volt signal at terminal 23.
With the selector switch (171) in the High position, the ECM sees a 0-volt signal at connector (1014) terminals 40 and 23.
